page.title: 18History of Abergavenny
page.content: Abergavenny means"At the mouth of the river of the fort of the Ironworkers" This shows that there were people in the area in prehistoric times.Remains have been found from the Neolithic and Bronze Ages at Flannel St.There was a major Iron Age fort here where iron from Pwll du was smelted.The Romans called their fort Gobannium and part of its ditch and gate were found under the Post Office.A wooden castle was built by the Normans after the Conquest and replaced in stone around 1190.It was a marcher lordship with lords such as de Ballon,de Braose,Cantelupes,de Hastings,Beauchamp and Nevilles.The town grew up around the castle and market in the 13th century.St Mary's Church was once a Benedictine priory for a prior and 12 monks.St John's parish church became King Henry VIII Free Grammar School in 1542.
